column4: {"{\\"id\\":0,\\"label\\":\\"Population Growth\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different population growth projections until the end year of the analysis (2030). Annual growth variants (2018-2030) were retrieved from UN Population database. Medium population growth scenario uses the medium growth variant; High population growth scenario uses the high growth variant.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Medium population growth (2%)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High population growth (2.3%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Electricity demand target\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the electricity demand target expressed in kWh/capita/year. The top-down scenarios introduce consistent Tier-based demand targets across all settlements based on their urban (U) and rural (R) status. In the low demand scenario, the urban demand target is informed by the average consumption observed in currently electrified areas in the country, translated into the nearest access Tier (e.g. U4 – Urban Tier 4). Low rural demand target is always set to Tier 1 (e.g. R1 – Rural Tier 1). The high demand target scenario reflects more aggressive goals. Urban demand target is increased by 1 Tier, unless already Tier 5, while rural demand target is increased by 2 Tiers. The bottom-up scenario assigns a unique demand target (kWh/cap/year) in each settlement, based on local poverty rate and GDP level.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - Low (U3R1)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - High (U4R3)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Bottom-up demand target (Poverty-GDP)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"label\\":\\"Intermediate investment plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Indicates the electrification rate to be achieved in the first few years of the analysis (2025). In GEP it is assumed that final electrification rate is 100%, analysis considers 12 years (2018-2030) with an intermediate time step of 7 years. Not capped scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases linearly over the modelling years; no restrictions are set in terms of feasible grid connections per year. Capped growth scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases as in the first scenario but is subject to grid connections limitation, equal to 2.5% of population per year. In this case, grid electrified population slowly ramps up over the years of analysis following often an S-like curve.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Not capped\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Capped annual connections\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Grid generating cost of electricity\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different average costs of generating electricity by the power plants connected to the national grid. This cost is one of the factors that affect the LCoE of connecting to the grid (together with extension of the grid lines etc.), and can affect the split between grid- and off-grid technologies. Estimated on-grid cost scenario assumes an optimal generating cost of electricity by the central grid based on the Electricity Model Base for Africa (TEMBA).  High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.059 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.07375 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}
column5: {"{\\"id\\":0,\\"key\\":\\"Pop\\",\\"label\\":\\"Cluster's population\\",\\"timestep\\":true,\\"type\\":\\"range\\",\\"range\\":{\\"min\\":1,\\"max\\":756797}}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"key\\":\\"GridCellArea\\",\\"label\\":\\"Cluster's area (sq.km)\\",\\"timestep\\":false,\\"type\\":\\"range\\",\\"range\\":{\\"min\\":0,\\"max\\":78}}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"key\\":\\"FinalElecCode\\",\\"label\\":\\"Electrification Technology\\",\\"timestep\\":true,\\"type\\":\\"options\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Grid extension\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Stand-alone - Photovoltaic\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Mini-grid - Photovoltaic\\"},{\\"id\\":3,\\"value\\":6,\\"label\\":\\"Mini-grid - Wind\\"},{\\"id\\":4,\\"value\\":7,\\"label\\":\\"Mini-grid - Hydro\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"key\\":\\"CurrentMVLineDist\\",\\"label\\":\\"Distance from existing MV network (km)\\",\\"timestep\\":false,\\"type\\":\\"range\\",\\"range\\":{\\"min\\":0,\\"max\\":92}}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"key\\":\\"RoadDist\\",\\"label\\":\\"Distance from existing road network (km)\\",\\"timestep\\":false,\\"type\\":\\"range\\",\\"range\\":{\\"min\\":0,\\"max\\":102}}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"key\\":\\"InvestmentCapita\\",\\"label\\":\\"Investment cost per capita ($)\\",\\"timestep\\":true,\\"type\\":\\"range\\",\\"range\\":{\\"min\\":14,\\"max\\":2282}}"}

column9: This model is developed using the Open Source Spatial Electrification Tool (OnSSET). Full access to the source code behind this model is available at https://github.com/global-electrification-platform. For more information on the functionality of the model please contact the development team at KTH.

Full access to the source code behind this model is available at https://github.com/global-electrification-platform. For more information on the functionality of the model please contact the development team at KTH.

column4: {"{\\"id\\":0,\\"label\\":\\"Population Growth\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different population growth projections until the end year of the analysis (2030). Annual growth variants (2018-2030) were retrieved from UN Population database. Medium population growth scenario uses the medium growth variant; High population growth scenario uses the high growth variant.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Medium population growth (2%)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High population growth (2.3%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Electricity demand target\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the electricity demand target expressed in kWh/capita/year. The top-down scenarios introduce consistent Tier-based demand targets across all settlements based on their urban (U) and rural (R) status. In the low demand scenario, the urban demand target is informed by the average consumption observed in currently electrified areas in the country, translated into the nearest access Tier (e.g. U4 – Urban Tier 4). Low rural demand target is always set to Tier 1 (e.g. R1 – Rural Tier 1). The high demand target scenario reflects more aggressive goals. Urban demand target is increased by 1 Tier, unless already Tier 5, while rural demand target is increased by 2 Tiers. The bottom-up scenario assigns a unique demand target (kWh/cap/year) in each settlement, based on local poverty rate and GDP level.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - Low (U5R1)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - High (U5R3)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Bottom-up demand target (Poverty-GDP)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"label\\":\\"Intermediate investment plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Indicates the electrification rate to be achieved in the first few years of the analysis (2025). In GEP it is assumed that final electrification rate is 100%, analysis considers 12 years (2018-2030) with an intermediate time step of 7 years. Not capped scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases linearly over the modelling years; no restrictions are set in terms of feasible grid connections per year. Capped growth scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases as in the first scenario but is subject to grid connections limitation, equal to 2.5% of population per year. In this case, grid electrified population slowly ramps up over the years of analysis following often an S-like curve.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Not capped\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Capped annual connections\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Grid generating cost of electricity\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different average costs of generating electricity by the power plants connected to the national grid. This cost is one of the factors that affect the LCoE of connecting to the grid (together with extension of the grid lines etc.), and can affect the split between grid- and off-grid technologies. Estimated on-grid cost scenario assumes an optimal generating cost of electricity by the central grid based on the Electricity Model Base for Africa (TEMBA).  High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.039 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.04875 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}
column5: {"{\\"id\\":0,\\"key\\":\\"Pop\\",\\"label\\":\\"Cluster's population\\",\\"timestep\\":true,\\"type\\":\\"range\\",\\"range\\":{\\"min\\":2,\\"max\\":1683266}}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"key\\":\\"GridCellArea\\",\\"label\\":\\"Cluster's area (sq.km)\\",\\"timestep\\":false,\\"type\\":\\"range\\",\\"range\\":{\\"min\\":0,\\"max\\":241}}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"key\\":\\"FinalElecCode\\",\\"label\\":\\"Electrification Technology\\",\\"timestep\\":true,\\"type\\":\\"options\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Grid extension\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Stand-alone - Photovoltaic\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Mini-grid - Photovoltaic\\"},{\\"id\\":3,\\"value\\":6,\\"label\\":\\"Mini-grid - Wind\\"},{\\"id\\":4,\\"value\\":7,\\"label\\":\\"Mini-grid - Hydro\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"key\\":\\"CurrentMVLineDist\\",\\"label\\":\\"Distance from existing MV network (km)\\",\\"timestep\\":false,\\"type\\":\\"range\\",\\"range\\":{\\"min\\":0,\\"max\\":223}}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"key\\":\\"RoadDist\\",\\"label\\":\\"Distance from existing road network (km)\\",\\"timestep\\":false,\\"type\\":\\"range\\",\\"range\\":{\\"min\\":0,\\"max\\":160}}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"key\\":\\"InvestmentCapita\\",\\"label\\":\\"Investment cost per capita ($)\\",\\"timestep\\":true,\\"type\\":\\"range\\",\\"range\\":{\\"min\\":23,\\"max\\":3654}}"}

The data that comes from OpenStreetMap and World Bank project archives.","source":{"label":"energydata.info","url":"https://energydata.info"},"vectorLayers":["data_layer"]},{"id":"healthsites","label":"Healthsites","type":"vector","url":"mapbox://derilinx.Healthsites","description":"This dataset shows the list of operating health facilities.","source":{"label":"Global Healthsites Mapping Project","url":"https://data.humdata.org"},"vectorLayers":["healthsites"]},{"id":"schools","label":"Schools (OpenStreetMap)","type":"vector","url":"mapbox://derilinx.Schools","description":"This dataset shows the schools from OpenStreetMap.","source":{"label":"OpenStreetMap","url":"https://www.openstreetmap.org"},"vectorLayers":["schools"]},{"id":"wind-potential","label":"Wind Potential (2015)","type":"vector","url":"https://energydata-tiles-bk.s3.amazonaws.com/tiles/faaec345-c386-4cd7-832f-e70443fd2fa2-77d89202-a356-4dee-86c2-c9e2880fab46/data.tilejson","description":"Polygons show optimal locations for wind power generation.","source":{"label":"MapRE","url":"https://mapre.lbl.gov/"},"vectorLayers":["data_layer"]}],"techLayersConfig":[{"id":"1","label":"Grid","color":"#73B2FF"},{"id":"2","label":"Stand-alone - Diesel","color":"#fe5931"},{"id":"3","label":"Stand-alone - Photovoltaic","color":"#FFD38C"},{"id":"4","label":"Mini-grid - Diesel","color":"#8fb722"},{"id":"5","label":"Mini-grid - Photovoltaic","color":"#E6AF00"},{"id":"6","label":"Mini-grid - Wind","color":"#8F77AD"},{"id":"7","label":"Mini-grid - Hydro","color":"#00518E"}]}

column9: This model is developed using the Open Source Spatial Electrification Tool (OnSSET). Full access to the source code behind this model is available at https://github.com/global-electrification-platform. For more information on the functionality of the model please contact the development team at KTH.

column4: {"{\\"id\\":0,\\"label\\":\\"Population Growth\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different population growth projections until the end year of the analysis (2030). Annual growth variants (2018-2030) were retrieved from UN Population database. Medium population growth scenario uses the medium growth variant; High population growth scenario uses the high growth variant.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Medium population growth (2%)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High population growth (2.3%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Electricity demand target\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the electricity demand target expressed in kWh/capita/year. The top-down scenarios introduce consistent Tier-based demand targets across all settlements based on their urban (U) and rural (R) status. In the low demand scenario, the urban demand target is informed by the average consumption observed in currently electrified areas in the country, translated into the nearest access Tier (e.g. U4 – Urban Tier 4). Low rural demand target is always set to Tier 1 (e.g. R1 – Rural Tier 1). The high demand target scenario reflects more aggressive goals. Urban demand target is increased by 1 Tier, unless already Tier 5, while rural demand target is increased by 2 Tiers. The bottom-up scenario assigns a unique demand target (kWh/cap/year) in each settlement, based on local poverty rate and GDP level.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - Low (U2R1)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - High (U3R3)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Bottom-up demand target (Poverty-GDP)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"label\\":\\"Intermediate investment plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Indicates the electrification rate to be achieved in the first few years of the analysis (2025). In GEP it is assumed that final electrification rate is 100%, analysis considers 12 years (2018-2030) with an intermediate time step of 7 years. Not capped scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases linearly over the modelling years; no restrictions are set in terms of feasible grid connections per year. Capped growth scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases as in the first scenario but is subject to grid connections limitation, equal to 2.5% of population per year. In this case, grid electrified population slowly ramps up over the years of analysis following often an S-like curve.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Not capped\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Capped annual connections\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Grid generating cost of electricity\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different average costs of generating electricity by the power plants connected to the national grid. This cost is one of the factors that affect the LCoE of connecting to the grid (together with extension of the grid lines etc.), and can affect the split between grid- and off-grid technologies. Estimated on-grid cost scenario assumes an optimal generating cost of electricity by the central grid based on the Electricity Model Base for Africa (TEMBA).  High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.1 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.125 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

For more information on the functionality of the model please contact the development team at KTH.

column4: {"{\\"id\\":0,\\"label\\":\\"Population Growth\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different population growth projections until the end year of the analysis (2030). Annual growth variants (2018-2030) were retrieved from UN Population database. Medium population growth scenario uses the medium growth variant; High population growth scenario uses the high growth variant.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Medium population growth (2%)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High population growth (2.3%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Electricity demand target\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the electricity demand target expressed in kWh/capita/year. The top-down scenarios introduce consistent Tier-based demand targets across all settlements based on their urban (U) and rural (R) status. In the low demand scenario, the urban demand target is informed by the average consumption observed in currently electrified areas in the country, translated into the nearest access Tier (e.g. U4 – Urban Tier 4). Low rural demand target is always set to Tier 1 (e.g. R1 – Rural Tier 1). The high demand target scenario reflects more aggressive goals. Urban demand target is increased by 1 Tier, unless already Tier 5, while rural demand target is increased by 2 Tiers. The bottom-up scenario assigns a unique demand target (kWh/cap/year) in each settlement, based on local poverty rate and GDP level.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - Low (U3R1)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - High (U4R3)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Bottom-up demand target (Poverty-GDP)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"label\\":\\"Intermediate investment plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Indicates the electrification rate to be achieved in the first few years of the analysis (2025). In GEP it is assumed that final electrification rate is 100%, analysis considers 12 years (2018-2030) with an intermediate time step of 7 years. Not capped scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases linearly over the modelling years; no restrictions are set in terms of feasible grid connections per year. Capped growth scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases as in the first scenario but is subject to grid connections limitation, equal to 2.5% of population per year. In this case, grid electrified population slowly ramps up over the years of analysis following often an S-like curve.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Not capped\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Capped annual connections\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Grid generating cost of electricity\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different average costs of generating electricity by the power plants connected to the national grid. This cost is one of the factors that affect the LCoE of connecting to the grid (together with extension of the grid lines etc.), and can affect the split between grid- and off-grid technologies. Estimated on-grid cost scenario assumes an optimal generating cost of electricity by the central grid based on the Electricity Model Base for Africa (TEMBA).  High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.105 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.131 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.235 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.29375 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

column4: {"{\\"id\\":0,\\"label\\":\\"Population Growth\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different population growth projections until the end year of the analysis (2030). Annual growth variants (2018-2030) were retrieved from UN Population database. Medium population growth scenario uses the medium growth variant; High population growth scenario uses the high growth variant.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Medium population growth (2%)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High population growth (2.3%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Electricity demand target\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the electricity demand target expressed in kWh/capita/year. The top-down scenarios introduce consistent Tier-based demand targets across all settlements based on their urban (U) and rural (R) status. In the low demand scenario, the urban demand target is informed by the average consumption observed in currently electrified areas in the country, translated into the nearest access Tier (e.g. U4 � Urban Tier 4). Low rural demand target is always set to Tier 1 (e.g. R1 � Rural Tier 1). The high demand target scenario reflects more aggressive goals. Urban demand target is increased by 1 Tier, unless already Tier 5, while rural demand target is increased by 2 Tiers. The bottom-up scenario assigns a unique demand target (kWh/cap/year) in each settlement, based on local poverty rate and GDP level.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - Low (U4R1)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - High (U5R3)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Bottom-up demand target (Poverty-GDP)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"label\\":\\"Intermediate investment plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Indicates the electrification rate to be achieved in the first few years of the analysis (2025). In GEP it is assumed that final electrification rate is 100%, analysis considers 12 years (2018-2030) with an intermediate time step of 7 years. Not capped scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases linearly over the modelling years; no restrictions are set in terms of feasible grid connections per year. Capped growth scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases as in the first scenario but is subject to grid connections limitation, equal to 2.5% of population per year. In this case, grid electrified population slowly ramps up over the years of analysis following often an S-like curve.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Not capped\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Capped annual connections\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Grid generating cost of electricity\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different average costs of generating electricity by the power plants connected to the national grid. This cost is one of the factors that affect the LCoE of connecting to the grid (together with extension of the grid lines etc.), and can affect the split between grid- and off-grid technologies. Estimated on-grid cost scenario assumes an optimal generating cost of electricity by the central grid based on the Electricity Model Base for Africa (TEMBA).  High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.1 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.125 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers �forced� grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers �forced� grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

Low rural demand target is always set to Tier 1 (e.g. R1 – Rural Tier 1). The high demand target scenario reflects more aggressive goals. Urban demand target is increased by 1 Tier, unless already Tier 5, while rural demand target is increased by 2 Tiers. The bottom-up scenario assigns a unique demand target (kWh/cap/year) in each settlement, based on local poverty rate and GDP level.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - Low (U3R1)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - High (U4R3)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Bottom-up demand target (Poverty-GDP)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"label\\":\\"Intermediate investment plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Indicates the electrification rate to be achieved in the first few years of the analysis (2025). In GEP it is assumed that final electrification rate is 100%, analysis considers 12 years (2018-2030) with an intermediate time step of 7 years. Not capped scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases linearly over the modelling years; no restrictions are set in terms of feasible grid connections per year. Capped growth scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases as in the first scenario but is subject to grid connections limitation, equal to 2.5% of population per year. In this case, grid electrified population slowly ramps up over the years of analysis following often an S-like curve.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Not capped\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Capped annual connections\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Grid generating cost of electricity\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different average costs of generating electricity by the power plants connected to the national grid. This cost is one of the factors that affect the LCoE of connecting to the grid (together with extension of the grid lines etc.), and can affect the split between grid- and off-grid technologies. Estimated on-grid cost scenario assumes an optimal generating cost of electricity by the central grid based on the Electricity Model Base for Africa (TEMBA).  High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.030 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.038 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

column9: This model is developed using the Open Source Spatial Electrification Tool (OnSSET). Full access to the source code behind this model is available at https://github.com/global-electrification-platform. For more information on the functionality of the model please contact the development team at KTH.

column4: {"{\\"id\\":0,\\"label\\":\\"Population Growth\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different population growth projections until the end year of the analysis (2030). Annual growth variants (2018-2030) were retrieved from UN Population database. Medium population growth scenario uses the medium growth variant; High population growth scenario uses the high growth variant.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Medium population growth (2.5%)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High population growth (2.8%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Electricity demand target\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the electricity demand target expressed in kWh/capita/year. The top-down scenarios introduce consistent Tier-based demand targets across all settlements based on their urban (U) and rural (R) status. In the low demand scenario, the urban demand target is informed by the average consumption observed in currently electrified areas in the country, translated into the nearest access Tier (e.g. U4 – Urban Tier 4). Low rural demand target is always set to Tier 1 (e.g. R1 – Rural Tier 1). The high demand target scenario reflects more aggressive goals. Urban demand target is increased by 1 Tier, unless already Tier 5, while rural demand target is increased by 2 Tiers. The bottom-up scenario assigns a unique demand target (kWh/cap/year) in each settlement, based on local poverty rate and GDP level.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - Low (U3R1)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - High (U4R3)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Bottom-up demand target (Poverty-GDP)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"label\\":\\"Intermediate investment plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Indicates the electrification rate to be achieved in the first few years of the analysis (2025). In GEP it is assumed that final electrification rate is 100%, analysis considers 12 years (2018-2030) with an intermediate time step of 7 years. Not capped scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases linearly over the modelling years; no restrictions are set in terms of feasible grid connections per year. Capped growth scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases as in the first scenario but is subject to grid connections limitation, equal to 2.5% of population per year. In this case, grid electrified population slowly ramps up over the years of analysis following often an S-like curve.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Not capped\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Capped annual connections\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Grid generating cost of electricity\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different average costs of generating electricity by the power plants connected to the national grid. This cost is one of the factors that affect the LCoE of connecting to the grid (together with extension of the grid lines etc.), and can affect the split between grid- and off-grid technologies. Estimated on-grid cost scenario assumes an optimal generating cost of electricity by the central grid based on the Electricity Model Base for Africa (TEMBA).  High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.015 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.019 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

column9: This model is developed using the Open Source Spatial Electrification Tool (OnSSET). Full access to the source code behind this model is available at https://github.com/global-electrification-platform. For more information on the functionality of the model please contact the development team at KTH.

column4: {"{\\"id\\":0,\\"label\\":\\"Population Growth\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different population growth projections until the end year of the analysis (2030). Annual growth variants (2018-2030) were retrieved from UN Population database. Medium population growth scenario uses the medium growth variant; High population growth scenario uses the high growth variant.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Medium population growth (2.9%)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High population growth (3.1%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Electricity demand target\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the electricity demand target expressed in kWh/capita/year. The top-down scenarios introduce consistent Tier-based demand targets across all settlements based on their urban (U) and rural (R) status. In the low demand scenario, the urban demand target is informed by the average consumption observed in currently electrified areas in the country, translated into the nearest access Tier (e.g. U4 – Urban Tier 4). Low rural demand target is always set to Tier 1 (e.g. R1 – Rural Tier 1). The high demand target scenario reflects more aggressive goals. Urban demand target is increased by 1 Tier, unless already Tier 5, while rural demand target is increased by 2 Tiers. The bottom-up scenario assigns a unique demand target (kWh/cap/year) in each settlement, based on local poverty rate and GDP level.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - Low (U3R1)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - High (U4R3)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Bottom-up demand target (Poverty-GDP)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"label\\":\\"Intermediate investment plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Indicates the electrification rate to be achieved in the first few years of the analysis (2025). In GEP it is assumed that final electrification rate is 100%, analysis considers 12 years (2018-2030) with an intermediate time step of 7 years. Not capped scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases linearly over the modelling years; no restrictions are set in terms of feasible grid connections per year. Capped growth scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases as in the first scenario but is subject to grid connections limitation, equal to 2.5% of population per year. In this case, grid electrified population slowly ramps up over the years of analysis following often an S-like curve.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Not capped\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Capped annual connections\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Grid generating cost of electricity\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different average costs of generating electricity by the power plants connected to the national grid. This cost is one of the factors that affect the LCoE of connecting to the grid (together with extension of the grid lines etc.), and can affect the split between grid- and off-grid technologies. Estimated on-grid cost scenario assumes an optimal generating cost of electricity by the central grid based on the Electricity Model Base for Africa (TEMBA).  High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.033 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.041 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.012 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.015 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

column4: {"{\\"id\\":0,\\"label\\":\\"Population Growth\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different population growth projections until the end year of the analysis (2030). Annual growth variants (2018-2030) were retrieved from UN Population database. Medium population growth scenario uses the medium growth variant; High population growth scenario uses the high growth variant.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Medium population growth (1.2%)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High population growth (1.5%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Electricity demand target\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the electricity demand target expressed in kWh/capita/year. The top-down scenarios introduce consistent Tier-based demand targets across all settlements based on their urban (U) and rural (R) status. In the low demand scenario, the urban demand target is informed by the average consumption observed in currently electrified areas in the country, translated into the nearest access Tier (e.g. U4 – Urban Tier 4). Low rural demand target is always set to Tier 1 (e.g. R1 – Rural Tier 1). The high demand target scenario reflects more aggressive goals. Urban demand target is increased by 1 Tier, unless already Tier 5, while rural demand target is increased by 2 Tiers. The bottom-up scenario assigns a unique demand target (kWh/cap/year) in each settlement, based on local poverty rate and GDP level.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - Low (U3R1)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - High (U4R3)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Bottom-up demand target (Poverty-GDP)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"label\\":\\"Intermediate investment plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Indicates the electrification rate to be achieved in the first few years of the analysis (2025). In GEP it is assumed that final electrification rate is 100%, analysis considers 12 years (2018-2030) with an intermediate time step of 7 years. Not capped scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases linearly over the modelling years; no restrictions are set in terms of feasible grid connections per year. Capped growth scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases as in the first scenario but is subject to grid connections limitation, equal to 2.5% of population per year. In this case, grid electrified population slowly ramps up over the years of analysis following often an S-like curve.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Not capped\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Capped annual connections\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Grid generating cost of electricity\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different average costs of generating electricity by the power plants connected to the national grid. This cost is one of the factors that affect the LCoE of connecting to the grid (together with extension of the grid lines etc.), and can affect the split between grid- and off-grid technologies. Estimated on-grid cost scenario assumes an optimal generating cost of electricity by the central grid based on the Electricity Model Base for Africa (TEMBA).  High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.026 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.033 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

Medium population growth scenario uses the medium growth variant; High population growth scenario uses the high growth variant.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Medium population growth (2.5%)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High population growth (2.8%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Electricity demand target\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the electricity demand target expressed in kWh/capita/year. The top-down scenarios introduce consistent Tier-based demand targets across all settlements based on their urban (U) and rural (R) status. In the low demand scenario, the urban demand target is informed by the average consumption observed in currently electrified areas in the country, translated into the nearest access Tier (e.g. U4 – Urban Tier 4). Low rural demand target is always set to Tier 1 (e.g. R1 – Rural Tier 1). The high demand target scenario reflects more aggressive goals. Urban demand target is increased by 1 Tier, unless already Tier 5, while rural demand target is increased by 2 Tiers. The bottom-up scenario assigns a unique demand target (kWh/cap/year) in each settlement, based on local poverty rate and GDP level.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - Low (U3R1)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - High (U4R3)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Bottom-up demand target (Poverty-GDP)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"label\\":\\"Intermediate investment plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Indicates the electrification rate to be achieved in the first few years of the analysis (2025). In GEP it is assumed that final electrification rate is 100%, analysis considers 12 years (2018-2030) with an intermediate time step of 7 years. Not capped scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases linearly over the modelling years; no restrictions are set in terms of feasible grid connections per year. Capped growth scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases as in the first scenario but is subject to grid connections limitation, equal to 2.5% of population per year. In this case, grid electrified population slowly ramps up over the years of analysis following often an S-like curve.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Not capped\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Capped annual connections\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Grid generating cost of electricity\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different average costs of generating electricity by the power plants connected to the national grid. This cost is one of the factors that affect the LCoE of connecting to the grid (together with extension of the grid lines etc.), and can affect the split between grid- and off-grid technologies. Estimated on-grid cost scenario assumes an optimal generating cost of electricity by the central grid based on the Electricity Model Base for Africa (TEMBA).  High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.136 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.169 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

column9: This model is developed using the Open Source Spatial Electrification Tool (OnSSET). Full access to the source code behind this model is available at https://github.com/global-electrification-platform. For more information on the functionality of the model please contact the development team at KTH.

column9: This model is developed using the Open Source Spatial Electrification Tool (OnSSET). Full access to the source code behind this model is available at https://github.com/global-electrification-platform. For more information on the functionality of the model please contact the development team at KTH.

column4: {"{\\"id\\":0,\\"label\\":\\"Population Growth\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different population growth projections until the end year of the analysis (2030). Annual growth variants (2018-2030) were retrieved from UN Population database. Medium population growth scenario uses the medium growth variant; High population growth scenario uses the high growth variant.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Medium population growth (2.7%)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High population growth (3.0%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Electricity demand target\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the electricity demand target expressed in kWh/capita/year. The top-down scenarios introduce consistent Tier-based demand targets across all settlements based on their urban (U) and rural (R) status. In the low demand scenario, the urban demand target is informed by the average consumption observed in currently electrified areas in the country, translated into the nearest access Tier (e.g. U4 – Urban Tier 4). Low rural demand target is always set to Tier 1 (e.g. R1 – Rural Tier 1). The high demand target scenario reflects more aggressive goals. Urban demand target is increased by 1 Tier, unless already Tier 5, while rural demand target is increased by 2 Tiers. The bottom-up scenario assigns a unique demand target (kWh/cap/year) in each settlement, based on local poverty rate and GDP level.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - Low (U3R1)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - High (U4R3)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Bottom-up demand target (Poverty-GDP)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"label\\":\\"Intermediate investment plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Indicates the electrification rate to be achieved in the first few years of the analysis (2025). In GEP it is assumed that final electrification rate is 100%, analysis considers 12 years (2018-2030) with an intermediate time step of 7 years. Not capped scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases linearly over the modelling years; no restrictions are set in terms of feasible grid connections per year. Capped growth scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases as in the first scenario but is subject to grid connections limitation, equal to 2.5% of population per year. In this case, grid electrified population slowly ramps up over the years of analysis following often an S-like curve.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Not capped\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Capped annual connections\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Grid generating cost of electricity\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different average costs of generating electricity by the power plants connected to the national grid. This cost is one of the factors that affect the LCoE of connecting to the grid (together with extension of the grid lines etc.), and can affect the split between grid- and off-grid technologies. Estimated on-grid cost scenario assumes an optimal generating cost of electricity by the central grid based on the Electricity Model Base for Africa (TEMBA).  High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.017 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.021 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.060 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.075 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}

column4: {"{\\"id\\":0,\\"label\\":\\"Population Growth\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different population growth projections until the end year of the analysis (2030). Annual growth variants (2018-2030) were retrieved from UN Population database. Medium population growth scenario uses the medium growth variant; High population growth scenario uses the high growth variant.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Medium population growth (1.9%)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High population growth (2.2%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":1,\\"label\\":\\"Electricity demand target\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the electricity demand target expressed in kWh/capita/year. The top-down scenarios introduce consistent Tier-based demand targets across all settlements based on their urban (U) and rural (R) status. In the low demand scenario, the urban demand target is informed by the average consumption observed in currently electrified areas in the country, translated into the nearest access Tier (e.g. U4 – Urban Tier 4). Low rural demand target is always set to Tier 1 (e.g. R1 – Rural Tier 1). The high demand target scenario reflects more aggressive goals. Urban demand target is increased by 1 Tier, unless already Tier 5, while rural demand target is increased by 2 Tiers. The bottom-up scenario assigns a unique demand target (kWh/cap/year) in each settlement, based on local poverty rate and GDP level.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - Low (U5R1)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Top-down demand target - High (U5R3)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Bottom-up demand target (Poverty-GDP)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":2,\\"label\\":\\"Intermediate investment plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Indicates the electrification rate to be achieved in the first few years of the analysis (2025). In GEP it is assumed that final electrification rate is 100%, analysis considers 12 years (2018-2030) with an intermediate time step of 7 years. Not capped scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases linearly over the modelling years; no restrictions are set in terms of feasible grid connections per year. Capped growth scenario assumes that the electrification rate increases as in the first scenario but is subject to grid connections limitation, equal to 2.5% of population per year. In this case, grid electrified population slowly ramps up over the years of analysis following often an S-like curve.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Not capped\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Capped annual connections\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":3,\\"label\\":\\"Grid generating cost of electricity\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines different average costs of generating electricity by the power plants connected to the national grid. This cost is one of the factors that affect the LCoE of connecting to the grid (together with extension of the grid lines etc.), and can affect the split between grid- and off-grid technologies. Estimated on-grid cost scenario assumes an optimal generating cost of electricity by the central grid based on the Electricity Model Base for Africa (TEMBA).  High on-grid cost scenario assumes a generating cost of electricity by the central grid increased by 25% so as to account for deviations from the optimal plan (construction delays, deployment of emergency fossil fuel based units etc.), which can increase generating cost affecting thus the split between grid- and off-grid technologies.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Estimated on-grid cost (0.038 $/kWh)\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High on-grid cost (0.048 $/kWh)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":4,\\"label\\":\\"PV system cost\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the role of PV system costs on electrification results. It should be noted that these costs, as used in GEP, reflect both PV module cost and Balance of System (BoS) expressed in $/kW. Expected PV cost scenario considers PV system costs as expected to vary in the modeling period. Low PV cost scenario considers PV system costs decreased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values. High PV cost scenario considers PV system costs increased by 25% compared to the expected scenario values.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Expected PV cost\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"High PV cost (+25%)\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Low PV cost (-25%)\\"}]}","{\\"id\\":5,\\"label\\":\\"Rollout plan\\",\\"description\\":\\"Definition: Examines the potential of electrification rollout plans for the country. Nationwide least cost approach works as follows: First, connections are ramped up in all already grid connected settlements. Then, un-electrified settlements are prioritized based on lowest investment cost per capita until the target electrification rate is reached. Note! a generation capacity limit for the centralized grid is applied in order to keep grid expansion to sensible levels. Grid connection within 1 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 1km from existing MV network. Grid connection within 2 km presents a rollout plan that considers “forced” grid connection in all settlements located within 2km from existing MV network.\\",\\"options\\":[{\\"id\\":0,\\"value\\":\\"Nationwide Least Cost approach\\"},{\\"id\\":1,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 1 km\\"},{\\"id\\":2,\\"value\\":\\"Grid connection within 2 km\\"}]}"}
